page.title: 01INTRODUCTION TO THE AREA
page.content: Our area, once a settlement of the Jutish Tribe, Meonwara, has the River Meon flowing through Westbury to West Meon village where it begins its southward course. Westbury, in the Domesday book a manor valued at "three hides", was the venue for a treaty between Henry I and Robert, Duke of Normandy. The present house was a refuge for City of London records in World War Two, a prep. school and a nursing home. West Meon was once the home of Thomas Lord, of M.C.C.fame, Richard Cobden, apostle of Free Trade, Thorold Rogers, authoritative writer on agricultural economy, and Guy Burgess, Twentieth century spy and defector. In 1985 it is described by estate agents as a much favoured area with attractive coutryside, rural aspects and varied housing.
